stem: The nurse is inserting an oropharyngeal airway (OPA) in an unconscious client without a gag reflex. Place the steps in the correct order.

options.text: Check for air movement and position of the flange against the lips.
Measure from the corner of the mouth to the angle of the jaw.
Insert the OPA with the tip pointing toward the roof of the mouth (upwards).
Advance the OPA until it reaches the soft palate, then rotate 180 degrees.
Open the client's mouth using the cross-finger technique.

rationale.correct: OPA insertion prevents the tongue from obstructing the airway. (1) Sizing prevents trauma or airway worsening. (2) Opening the mouth safely. (3/4) Entering upwards and rotating 180 degrees ensures the tongue is pushed down and the airway follows the natural curve of the oropharynx without pushing the tongue into the throat. (5) Verification.
rationale.incorrect: Inserting the OPA directly following the curve of the mouth (pointing down) in an adult can push the tongue back and cause obstruction.
clinicalPearls: If the client begins to gag or regain consciousness, remove the OPA immediately to prevent vomiting and aspiration.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember 'Corner of Mouth to Jaw' for OPA. Do not confuse with 'Nose to Ear' (NPA).

reviewUnits.heading: Airway Management: Oropharyngeal Airway (OPA)
reviewUnits.body: Nurses monitor for airway obstruction and aspiration risk. OPAs are used ONLY in unconscious patients with no gag reflex.
